addressleaf.section:
From S
r
Frauncis Walsingham dated the 23 of June 1589

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 23 June To M
r
Bodly
S
r
I send you hereinclosed aswell the gene-
rall articles whereof mention is made in my
lordes letters, and of the w
ch
there hath ben a
translated Coppie in Frenche delyvered to
the States deputies here, from whom I
thincke the
States
there will receave them
before the arryvall of these letters unto you:
as also to the
ticular heades w
ch
you are
willed by my lordes to Communicate as from
yo
r
self to Certeine of the said States.
You are to Call earnestlie uppon them that her
Ma
tie
maie receave satisfaction to the [grewes]
of the Captens whereof you shall also herein-
closed receave a Coppie; for that her Ma
tie
findeth it strange that notw
th
standing the
often sollicitacions made on their behalf
both by
M
r
Killegrewe
, yo
r
self, and lately
by
Mons
r
Caron
, she receaveth noe other then
a generall answeare from them, and therefore
you are to deale earnestlie w
th
them, that
their deputies maie be aucthorised to geve
her
ticuler satisfaction therein.
There have passed of late hoate wourdes
betweene the lordes and the deputies here
uppon the occasion of the Callumnations
Conteyned in the placcard against the
lord
Willoughbie
: in the answearing whereof
they Carried them selfes w
th
greater loftines
and insolencie, then in former tymes they have
at ani tyme used, w
ch
proud humor so
newelie put on, Cannott but argue a
vehement p
r
sumption that they doe deryve
a hope from some place, either of supporte
from
France
when the
King
shall have
mastred the league or that they Can make
their peace w
th
Spayne,
or ells that they
shalbe able to defend them selfes w
th
out her
ma
ts
assistance, And therefore you shall doe
well to seeke by all the meanes you maie to
fol.307v
decipher uppon whatt grownd they are
growne to this newe Corage whether you
maie use my good frende
M
r
Gilpins
assi-
stance.
The deputies here have delyvered unto the
lordes the Coppies of such letters as were written
by
Vasseur,
and althoughe they are to be
disliked yett doe they not Conteine anie such
matter, but that both the examination and puni- shement might have ben reserved over unto her
ma
tie
, w
th
out ani such severe manner of
ceading as is nowe by them held, w
ch
Cannot
be maintained in Course o f justice as by the
inclosed maie appeare unto you. Her ma
ts
pleasure is you shall deale effectuallie w
th
the States in moving them in her name that
the partye maie be either released, or ells
his
son, and the recognition of his Cause
transferred hither.
And so I Comitt
you to god From the Cort at Noonesuch
the 23
th
of June
1589
.
Yo
r
assured frend, Francis Walsyngham
